[[Persija Jakarta]] (2008–2016, 2018–present)[https://m.bola.com/indonesia/read/2482223/persija-hanya-bermarkas-di-senayan-hingga-jelang-bulan-ramadhan Persija Hanya Bermarkas di Senayan hingga Jelang Bulan Ramadhan][https://bolalob.com/read/101173/hadapi-persela-persija-kembali-ke-senayan Hadapi Persela, Persija Kembali ke Senayan] | capacity = 77,193{{cite web |url=https://reservation.gbk.id/venue/id_stadion-utama-gelora-bung-karno |title= E-Booking Stadion Utama Gelora Bung Karno |website=gbk.id |access-date=3 October 2018}}
{{Collapsible list|title=Capacity history|110,000 (1962–2007)
88,306 (2007–2016)
77,193 (2018–present)}} | record_attendance = {{formatnum: 150,000}}
{{nowrap|[[Persib Bandung]] v [[PSMS Medan]]}}
(23 February 1985){{cite web|url=http://bola.kompas.com/read/2017/03/25/11131398/jelang.psms.vs.persib.kenangan.rekor.150.000.penonton.di.senayan|title=Jelang PSMS vs Persib, Kenangan Rekor 150.000 Penonton di Senayan|publisher=[[Kompas Gramedia Group]]|work=Kompas.com|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=10 December 2017|language=id}}{{Dubious|date=October 2018}} | dimensions = {{convert|105|by|68|m|abbr=on}} | suites = 4{{Cite news|url=https://sport.detik.com/sepakbola/foto-sepakbola/d-3812384/stadion-utama-gbk-juga-dilengkapi-empat-sky-box/|title=Stadion Utama GBK juga Dilengkapi Empat Sky Box|last=Zafna|first=Grandyos|work=Detik.com|access-date=21 January 2018|date=12 January 2018|language=id}} }} '''Gelora Bung Karno Main Stadium''' ({{lang-id|Stadion Utama Gelora Bung Karno}}; literally "Bung Karno Sports Arena Main Stadium") is a multi-purpose stadium located at the center of the [[Gelora Bung Karno Sports Complex]] in [[Central Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]]. The stadium is named after [[Sukarno]], Indonesia's first [[List of Presidents of Indonesia|President]]. It is mostly used for [[association football|football]] matches. When first opened prior to the [[1962 Asian Games]] (Asiad), the stadium had a seating capacity of 110,000. It has been reduced twice: first to 88,306 in 2006 for the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]] and second to 77,193 between 2016 and 2017 for the [[2018 Asian Games|2018 Asiad]] (Asiad) and [[2018 Asian Para Games|Asian Para Games]]. In the 2016–17 renovations, all spectator benches are replaced by single seats. The 88,306 capacity made it the [[List of association football stadiums by capacity|7th largest association football stadium in the world]]. Today it is the 28th largest association football stadium in the world and 8th largest association football stadium in Asia. Since its opening, it holds record as the largest stadium in Indonesia. The [[2007 AFC Asian Cup Final]] took place in the stadium. During the 2018 Asiad, the stadium hosted the [[2018 Asian Games opening ceremony|opening]] and [[2018 Asian Games closing ceremony|closing]] ceremonies and also its [[Athletics at the 2018 Asian Games|entire athletics events]] in between, while it used as the [[2018 Asian Para Games opening and closing ceremonies#Opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] and [[Athletics at the 2018 Asian Para Games|athletics competition]] venue for the 2018 Asian Para Games. ==Naming history== Although the stadium is popularly known as Gelora Bung Karno Stadium (''Stadion Gelora Bung Karno'') or ''GBK'' Stadium, its official name is Gelora Bung Karno Main Stadium (''Stadion Utama Gelora Bung Karno''), as there are other stadiums in the [[Gelora Bung Karno Sports Complex]], such as the [[Istora Gelora Bung Karno|Sports Palace]] and the [[Gelora Bung Karno Madya Stadium|secondary stadium]]. It was known as Senajan ([[Enhanced Indonesian Spelling System|EYD]]: Senayan) Main Stadium from its opening through the 1962 Asiad until the complex's name was changed to Gelora Bung Karno by a Presidential Decree issued on 24 September 1962, twenty days after the games ended. During the [[New Order (Indonesia)|New Order]] era, the complex was renamed "Gelora Senayan Complex" and the stadium was renamed "Gelora Senayan Main Stadium" in 1969 under the "[[de-Sukarnoization]]" policy by then-President [[Suharto]]. After the fall of the dictatorship, the complex name was reverted by President [[Abdurrahman Wahid]] on a Presidential Decree effective since 17 January 2001. ==History== [[File:Gelora Bung Karno 1962.jpg|thumb|right|220px|The stadium under construction, April 1962.]] [[File:Gelora Bung Karno Stadium in 180-degree view; October 2011.jpeg|thumb|220px|right|The massive roof ring structure popularly dubbed as ''Temu Gelang'' by [[Sukarno]]]] Construction began on 8 February 1960 and finished on 21 July 1962,[http://www.asiarooms.com/travel-guide/indonesia/jakarta/entertainment-in-jakarta/sport-in-jakarta/major-sports-venues-in-jakarta/bung-karno-stadium-in-jakarta.html Bung Karno Stadium in Jakarta, Bung Karno Stadium, Bung Karno Stadium in Jakarta, Indonesia] in time to host the [[1962 Asian Games|following month's Asian Games]]. Its construction was partially funded through a special loan from the [[Soviet Union]]. The stadium's original capacity of 110,000 people was reduced to 88,306 as a result of renovations for the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]].[http://www.free-football.tv/news/Indonesia-Bahrain.html Indonesia v Bahrain (Group D) in Jakarta] It is divided into 24 sectors and 12 entrances, and into upper and lower stands. The special feature of this stadium is the huge steel roof construction that forms a gigantic ring called ''temu gelang'' (joined ring), something that was very rare in 1962. Other than to shade the spectators in all sectors from the heat of tropical sun, the purpose of this giant ring construction is also to emphasize the grandeur of the stadium.[https://books.google.com/books?id=-mvqG8YbuHQC&pg=PA82&lpg=PA82&dq=Temu+Gelang+Gelora&source=bl&ots=bWx2qd71mq&sig=6HVUtaHqhHlzSyHHeLkB48IBcjY&hl=id&ei=62D-TIHCGoTlrAfd5ZyHCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDMQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Temu%20Gelang%20Gelora&f=false M.F. Siregar, Matahari Olahraga Indonesia, page 82-83] ==Events hosted== [[File:GBK Main with lighting 1.jpg|thumb|right|During the 2018 Asian Games, the stadium was covered in changing colors LED lights.]] GBK Stadium hosted the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup#Final|2007 Asian Cup Final]] between [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] and [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]]. Other competitions held there are several [[AFF Championship|Tiger Cup]] finals and [[Piala Indonesia|domestic cup]] finals. ===International=== * Host of the [[1962 Asian Games|1962]] and [[2018 Asian Games|2018]] [[Asian Games]] * Host of the [[2018 Asian Para Games|2018]] [[Asian Para Games]] * Host of the [[GANEFO#1st GANEFO|1963]] [[GANEFO|Games of the New Emerging Forces]] * Host of [[Southeast Asian Games]] (in [[1979 Southeast Asian Games|1979]], [[1987 Southeast Asian Games|1987]], [[1997 Southeast Asian Games|1997]], and [[2011 Southeast Asian Games|2011]]) * Host of the [[Asian Athletics Championships]] (in [[1985 Asian Athletics Championships|1985]], [[1995 Asian Athletics Championships|1995]], and [[2000 Asian Athletics Championships|2000]]) * Host of the [[2002 AFF Championship|2002 Tiger Cup]] for 9 out of 10 Group A matches, semifinal matches, third place play-off, and the final. * Host of the [[2003 ASEAN Club Championship]]. * Host of the [[2004 AFF Championship|2004 Tiger Cup]] first leg semifinal match against [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] and first leg final match against [[Singapore national football team|Singapore]]. * Host of the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]] for 5 out of 6 Group D matches, quarterfinals between [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] and [[Uzbekistan national football team|Uzbekistan]], and the final. * Host of the [[2008 AFF Championship|2008 AFF Suzuki Cup]] for first leg semifinal match against [[Thailand national football team|Thailand]] * Host for the [[F.C. Bayern Munich]] 2008 Post-season Tour * Host of the [[2010 AFF Championship|2010 AFF Suzuki Cup]] for 5 out of 6 Group A matches, semifinal matches against the [[Philippines national football team|Philippines]], and second leg final match against [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] * Host for the [[LA Galaxy]] 2011 Asia-Pacific Post-season Tour * Host for all 2 matches of the [[Inter Milan]] 2012 Post-season Tour * Host for the [[Valencia CF]] 2012 Asia Preseason Tour (their only match outside Europe) * Host for the [[Arsenal F.C.]] 2013 Asia Preseason Tour * Host for the [[Liverpool F.C.]] 2013 Asia Preseason Tour * Host for the [[Chelsea F.C.]] 2013 Asia Preseason Tour * Host for the [[Juventus F.C.]] 2014 Asia Preseason Tour * Host of the 2014 Asian Dream Cup against [[Park Ji-sung]] and Friends, featuring footballers and celebrities, including the cast of [[Running Man (TV series)|Running Man]]. * Host for the [[A.S. Tour]] |{{n/a}} |- |3 May 2019 |[[Ed Sheeran]] |[[÷ Tour]] |{{tba}} |- |} ==Recent renovations== [[File:GBK Main Stadium new seats.jpg|thumb|180px|The new seats]] Indonesia hosted the [[2018 Asian Games]] and [[2018 Asian Para Games]] and the Gelora Bung Karno Main Stadium was chosen as both Games' main venue. Due to the age of this stadium, which already exceeded fifty years, the government renovated the stadium in order to meet the standards made by the [[Olympic Council of Asia]]. All of the colorful wooden long benches ([[bleacher]]s) that still remained when the renovation commenced were scrapped and replaced with single seats, ultimately made it an [[all-seater stadium]]. The old single seats which had been installed during earlier renovation were also replaced. The seats, colored red, white, and grey, created an illusion of waving [[Flag of Indonesia|Indonesian flag]]. Its lighting system was upgraded from 1200 [[lux]] to 3500 lux.{{cite news |last=Rahmat |first=Arby |date=12 January 2018 |title= Lampu Stadion GBK Saingi San Siro Milan|url=https://www.cnnindonesia.com/olahraga/20180112075320-142-268307/lampu-stadion-gbk-saingi-san-siro-milan|work=CNN Indonesia |access-date=14 January 2018|language=id}}{{cite news|last1=Baskoro|first1=Rangga|title=SU GBK Jadi Stadion Paling Terang Di Asia|url=http://wartakota.tribunnews.com/2018/01/12/su-gbk-jadi-stadion-paling-terang-di-asia|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Tribunnews.com|date=12 January 2018|language=id}} On the stadium's roof, there are 1,293 [[solar panel]]s installed.{{cite news|last1=Diah|first1=Femi|title=Wajah Terkini Stadion Utama GBK: Rasa Baru yang Makin Merah Putih|url=https://sport.detik.com/sport-lain/d-3663511/wajah-terkini-stadion-utama-gbk-rasa-baru-yang-makin-merah-putih|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Detik.com|date=29 September 2017|language=id}} After renovation, the stadium accommodates the needs of disabled users.{{cite news|last1=Raya|first1=Mercy|title=Stadion Utama GBK Sudah Lebih Ramah Disabilitas|url=https://sport.detik.com/sepakbola/liga-indonesia/3811762/stadion-utama-gbk-sudah-lebih-ramah-disabilitas|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Detik.com|date=12 January 2018|language=id}} {{Infobox sport governing body |name= Hong Kong Squash |logo= Logo_Hong_Kong_Squash.jpg |logosize= 300px |sport= [[Squash (sport)|Squash]] |abbrev = HKS |founded = |aff = |affdate = |region = [[Asian Squash Federation]] |regionyear = |location = [[Hong Kong]] |president = |chairman = David Mui |chiefexec = Karl Mak |secretary = Tony Kwok |coach = Tony Choi |womenscoach = |replaced = |prevfounded = |url = http://www.hksquash.org.hk |countryflag= Hong Kong }} '''Hong Kong Squash''' (HKS) is the National Organisation for [[squash (sport)|Squash]] in [[Hong Kong]].
Mission Statement : * To ensure that squash remains a strong, viable and growing Hong Kong sport and that [[Hong Kong]] aspires to be the leaders of [[squash (sport)|Squash]] in [[Asia]].
Objectives : *To develop the game of squash in [[Hong Kong]]. *To safeguard the game of squash and to maintain the rules and regulations of HK Squash in [[Hong Kong]]. *To represent Hong Kong's official membership of the [[World Squash Federation]], [[Asian Squash Federation]] and Sports Federation and [[Olympic Committee]]. *To arrange, regulate and manage international and local matches, championships and competitions. *Generally to do all such other acts and things as are incidental or conducive to the attainment of all or any of the above objects.
==External links== *[http://www.hksquash.org.hk Official site]
==See also== * [[Hong Kong men's national squash team]] * [[Hong Kong women's national squash team]] * [[Hong Kong Junior Open Squash|Hong Kong Junior Open]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Human Performance Center | image = File:Human Performance Center (New Orleans).jpg | caption = | fullname = Human Performance Center | former_names = Health & Physical Education Center | location = [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] | coordinates = {{coord|30.0275|N|90.0671|W|region:US-LA_type:edu|display=inline,title}} | opened = {{Start date|1969}} | owner = [[University of New Orleans]] | operator = [[University of New Orleans]] | surface = Multi-surface | capacity = 1,760 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[New Orleans Privateers men's basketball]]
(1969–1983; 2006–2008)
[[New Orleans Privateers#Intercollegiate sports|New Orleans Privateers women's basketball]]
(1975–1983; 2006–2008)
[[New Orleans Privateers#Intercollegiate sports|New Orleans Privateers volleyball]] (1975–2009; 2011–present) | embedded = | website = [http://www.unoprivateers.com/sports/2011/2/13/GEN_0213111218.aspx Human Performance Center] }} The '''Human Performance Center''' is a 1,760-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] on the campus of the [[University of New Orleans]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]].{{cite web| title=Human Performance Center|publisher=uno.edu|url=http://campusbooking.uno.edu/hpc.cfm|accessdate=2012-01-14}} It is the home venue for the [[New Orleans Privateers#Intercollegiate sports|New Orleans Privateers volleyball]] team. The arena became the permanent home of the volleyball team in 2012 following years of alternating between the Performance Center and [[Lakefront Arena]]. Since 2008, the Human Performance Center has been the home venue of the [[Big Easy Rollergirls]], New Orleans' [[WFTDA]] flat track roller derby league. ==History== The venue, known to fans as the "Chamber of Horrors",{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=g42TyP-V5C8C&lpg=PA69&pg=PA121 | page = 314 | title = ESPN College Basketball Encyclopedia: The Complete History of the Men's Game | first = Bill | last = Bradley | publisher = Random House, Inc. | year = 2009 | ISBN = 0-345-51392-4 }} was home to the [[New Orleans Privateers]] [[New Orleans Privateers men's basketball|men's basketball]] team from its inception in 1969–70 until the opening of [[Lakefront Arena]] in 1983. During that period, the venue was officially known as the Health & Physical Education Center. The arena was used as the temporary home of the UNO men's and [[New Orleans Privateers#Intercollegiate sports|women's]] basketball teams from the 2005-2006 season until 2008 while Lakefront Arena was being repaired following [[Hurricane Katrina]]. The facility has hosted [[Louisiana High School Athletic Association|LHSAA]] state wrestling tournaments. == References == {{reflist}} {{New Orleans Privateers men's basketball navbox}} {{University of New Orleans}} [[Category:Basketball venues in New Orleans]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in New Orleans]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Louisiana]] [[Category:New Orleans Privateers men's basketball]] [[Category:New Orleans Privateers women's basketball]] [[Category:New Orleans Privateers women's volleyball]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in New Orleans]] [[Category:1969 establishments in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1969]] {{Louisiana-stadium-stub}} {{NewOrleans-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Letní stadion | nickname = | image = | location = U Stadionu 1652
[[Pardubice]]
[[Czech Republic]] | coordinates = {{Coord|50.040958|15.771250|display=inline,title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} | broke_ground = | opened = 31 May 1931 | renovated = 1968 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Pardubice]] | operator = | surface = Grass | dimensions = 105x70 m | construction_cost = | architect = Karel Řepa, Ferdinand Potůček | former_names = Masarykův všesportovní stadion (1931-1948)
Gottwaldův stadion (1948) | tenants = [[SK DFO Pardubice]]
Pardubice Stallions | seating_capacity = 1,000 }} '''Letní stadion''' is a former multi-purpose [[stadium]] in [[Pardubice]], [[Czech Republic]]. From demolition in 1968 is intended only for [[association football|football]]. It is the home stadium of [[women's association football|women's football]] team [[SK DFO Pardubice]] and [[American football]] team Pardubice Stallions. Stadium capacity from the original 15,000 spectators dropped to just 1,000 spectators.[http://www.parpedie.cz/cti-zaznam.php?id=Letni_stadion Letní stadion] at Parpedie.cz {{cs li}}[http://www.erlebnis-stadion.de/?ground=46 Photo gallery and data] at Erlebnis-stadion.de {{de li}} == The future of the stadium == In August 2015 have political leadership of the city of Pardubice five plans for reconstruction from [[KPMG]] company.{{cite web|url=http://pardubice.idnes.cz/budoucnost-letniho-stadionu-v-pardubicich-je-stale-nejista-p4k-/pardubice-zpravy.aspx?c=A140814_2090530_pardubice-zpravy_jah|title=Záchrana fotbalového stadionu přijde až po volbách. Ale jisté to není|language=Czech|work=idnes.cz|date=14 August 2015|accessdate=17 September 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.facebook.com/letnistadion Letní stadion Pardubice] at Facebook {{cs li}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Letni Stadion Pardubice}} [[Category:Football venues in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1931]] [[Category:American football venues]] {{CzechRepublic-sports-venue-stub}}

page.title: List of American public address announcers
List of fatalities due to wingsuit flying

revision.comment: Added day of the month to Geoffrey Robson entry. Removed computer-game related entry from 30 Nov 2018.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} Fatalities from [[wingsuit flying]] have occurred almost from the inception of the sport. Below are listed the most notable ones, including when wingsuit practice was not the first cause of death.
==List of fatalities due to wingsuit flying== <!-- NOTE: Unsourced additions WILL BE removed --> ;16 September 1963: Stunt parachutist Gerard Masselin jumped from a [[biplane]] showing his wingsuit to the camera and was killed after his parachute failed to open.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.britishpathe.com/video/another-bird-man-gerard-masselin-dies| title=Another bird man Gerard Masselin dies |work=British Pathé|date=1963| accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref> ;13 April 1998: [[Patrick de Gayardon]] dies in Hawaii testing his pioneer wingsuits<ref>{{cite web |url=http://adventuresportsjournal.com/a-life-in-flight/|title=A Life in Flight: Wingsuit Pioneer Loci Jean-Albert, “The Flying Dude”|last1=Schatz|first1=Bryan |website= Adventure Sports Journal|publisher= Adventure Sports Journal|access-date=24 January 2018}}</ref> ;5 October 2003: [[Dwain Weston]], an Australian skydiver and holder of the 2002 BASE-jumping world title, died after hitting a railing on the [[Royal Gorge Bridge]] near [[Cañon City, Colorado]].<ref name="Herald 2">{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/10/07/1065292560465.html?from=storyrhs| title=Base jumper was 'meticulous'| journal=The Sydney Morning Herald| date=7 October 2003| accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="Jones">{{cite web | url=http://xtremesport4u.com/extreme-air-sports/the-legends-last-jump-on-the-last-day-whatever-happens-happens/| title=The Legend's last jump on the last day – whatever happens happens| last=Jones| first=Lola| publisher=XtremeSport| date=16 November 2008| accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref> This was not a BASE accident as he jumped from an airplane; it was technically an illegal jump as he used BASE equipment containing only one parachute (i.e., no reserve parachute, {{disputed inline|text=which is required to legally jump from an aircraft|reason=FAR wording is such that it only prescribes rules *if* a dual-parachute system is used. This has been tested, including by Luke Aikins in a no-parachute jump.|date=June 2017}}). The pilots were eventually reprimanded for allowing the jump. ;22 October 2004: [[Roland "Slim" Simpson]] was a well known Australian BASE jumper. On 6 October 2004, Roland Simpson leapt from the [[Jin Mao Tower]], the tallest skyscraper in China at the time, in a wingsuit. After a good jump and flight, his parachute opened with multiple line twists making it difficult to steer and he crashed onto an adjacent building. He went into a coma, and died several days later in Canberra Hospital.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/10/08/1097089572149.html |title=A leap too far: leading base jumper killed in Shanghai |publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=9 October 2004 |accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> ;16 February 2006: Chad Zielinski exited a DHC-6 Twin Otter, and he died upon impact into the sea, after a wingsuit flight over Belize. An inspection of his gear showed no attempt to deploy either main or reserve parachute. His gear did not have an automatic activation device installed. ;9 May 2007: American adventurer and TV personality Jimmy Hall, age 41, was on an expedition to [[Baffin Island]] in northern Canada. After several days of successful jumps, Hall attempted a wingsuit flight through a canyon. He failed to clear a ledge, and impacted the cliff.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/hawaii-tv-adventurer-died-in-nunavut-base-jumping-accident-agent-1.654592 |title=Hawaii TV adventurer died in Nunavut base jumping accident |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=14 May 2007 |accessdate=9 June 2016 }}</ref> ;26 March 2009: [[Shane McConkey]] was a professional skier and BASE jumper. McConkey was performing a complicated ski-BASE jump in Italy. He experienced problems when he attempted to release his skis, and as a result failed to deploy his parachute in time.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://adventure-journal.com/2009/03/skier-shane-mcconkey-killed-in-base-jumping-accident/ |title=Skier Shane McConkey Killed BASE-Jumping in Italy |publisher=adventure-journal.com |author=Steve Casimiro |date=26 March 2016 |accessdate=13 June 2016 }}</ref> ;28 August 2009: [[Eli Thompson (skydiver)|Eli Thompson]] died while performing a [[Wingsuit flying|wingsuit]] proximity-flying jump from a helicopter in the Swiss Alps. He accidentally hit the side of the mountain. ;12 April 2010: Geoffrey Robson died during a wingsuit BASE jump from [[Stellenbosch]], South Africa. He was a [[PhD]] candidate at [[ETH Zürich]] working on the mathematical modelling of the [[aerodynamics|aerodynamic]] characteristics of wingsuits. He was described by a former professor as "very careful [, taking] the sport seriously".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Base-jumper-was-very-careful-20100413 |title=Base jumper was very careful| publisher=News24, South Africa |year=2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.idsc.ethz.ch/the-institute/former-staff/Robson-Geoffrey.html |title=Geoffrey Robson| publisher=ETH Zürich |year=2010}}</ref> ;23 June 2012: Hervé le Gallou, who was, along with Dave McDonnell, one of the first persons to jump from the [[Burj Khalifa]], died wingsuiting on [[Grande Tête de l'Obiou]] in the French Alps.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newser.com/story/171588/how-a-mythic-base-jumper-met-his-untimely-end.html |title=How a Mythic Base Jumper Met His Untimely End |publisher=[[Newser]] |date=27 July 2013 |accessdate=12 June 2016 }}</ref> ;12 December 2012: Eiliv Ruud, 37, struck a vertical cliff and spiraled out of control during a wingsuit jump near [[Grand Canyon]] in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2243836/Eiliv-Ruud-Norwegian-BASE-jumper-plummets-1-000ft-death-near-Grand-Canyon.html |title=Norwegian BASE jumper plummets 1,000ft to his death near Grand Canyon when his parachute fails to open |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=6 December 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref> ;14 August 2013: [[Mark Sutton]], a British stuntman who had parachuted into the [[2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony]] as a [[James Bond]] character, was killed when he hit a ridge while wingsuit BASE-jumping near [[Martigny]], [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite news | title=London 2012 parachutist Mark Sutton killed |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23707434|publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=15 August 2013 |accessdate=15 August 2013}}</ref> He was participating in an event sponsored by [[Epic TV]], and a wingsuit expert stated that he appeared to have miscalculated the [[Grade (slope)|gradient]] of the ground he was flying over.<ref>{{cite news | title='First trip here to fly and loving it': Tragic last message of James Bond Olympics daredevil who died after crashing into mountain at 200km/h|first=Jill |last=Reilly |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2394288/Mark-Sutton-dies-Olympics-2012-James-Bond-stuntman-killed-jumping-accident.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490 |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=15 August 2013 |accessdate=15 August 2013 |location=London}}</ref> ;18 August 2013: Mario Richard, an American wingsuit flyer, died during a wingsuit BASE jump from Sass Pordoi in Italy's [[Dolomites]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.climbing.com/news/mario-richard-dies-in-base-jump-accident/ | title='Mario Richard Dies in BASE Jump Accident' | date=20 August 2013 | accessdate=20 August 2018}}</ref> ;23 August 2013: Álvaro Bultó, a Spanish wingsuit flier, died after a wingsuit BASE-jump in Switzerland.<ref>[http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/agencia-efe/130823/spanish-extreme-sportsman-alvaro-bulto-dies-while-skydiving Alvaro Bulto dies while skydiving] Global Post website</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efe.com/efe/noticias/america/destacada/fallece-alvaro-bulto-accidente-los-alpes-suizos/2/65/2111414 |title=Destacada | Agencia EFE |publisher=www.efe.com |date= |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> ;8 October 2013: Hungarian Viktor Kováts died in rural China during a trial flight for the world BASE-jump championships.<ref>Tomlinson, Simon (9 October 2013). [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2450785/Victor-Kovats-Hungarian-wingsuit-flyer-dies-accident.html "Victor Kovats, Hungarian Wingsuit Flyer, Dies in Accident"]. ''[[Daily Mail]]''.</ref> ;13 March 2014: Prolific climber, adventurer and BASE jumper Sean "Stanley" Leary was killed in a BASE jumping accident near [[Zion National Park]], Utah.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rockandice.com/lates-news/sean-stanley-leary-killed-base-jumping |title=Sean "Stanley" Leary Killed BASE Jumping |publisher=[[Rock & Ice]] |date=24 March 2014 |accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref> ;29 March 2014: Three experienced wingsuit flyers: New Zealander Dan Vicary (33), Frenchman Ludovic Woerth (34), and American Brian Drake (33), jumped from a helicopter over the [[Lütschental]] area near [[Bern]], [[Switzerland]]. They had planned to land in the valley, but took a wrong turn, flew over the wrong ridge, and crashed into an Alpine pasture. Vicary and Woerth were found dead; Drake died four days later in a hospital.<ref>[http://www.thelocal.ch/20140403/us-wingsuit-flyer-dies-after-weekend-accident ''US Wingsuit Flyer Dies After Weekend Accident'']; 3 April 2014; The Local; retrieved April 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.3news.co.nz/Swiss-wingsuit-crash-claims-third-victim/tabid/417/articleID/338700/Default.aspx "Swiss Wingsuit Crash Claims Third Victim"]. 3 News New Zealand. Retrieved April 2014.</ref> ;6 June 2014: [[Darío Barrio]], a famous Spanish TV Chef, owner of the Madrid restaurant Dassa Bassa and an experienced wingsuit flier, died in an accident while participating in the International Air Festival at [[Segura de la Sierra]] in [[Jaén, Spain|Jaén]], a province in southern [[Spain]]. Darío, aged 42, was supposed to fly over an old castle but, for unknown reasons, crashed into the cliff where the castle is located.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/dario-barrio-dead-spanish-tv-chef-killed-in-base-jumping-wingsuit-crash-9508055.html "Dario Barrio dead: Spanish TV chef killed in base jumping wingsuit crash"]. The Independent.</ref> ;2 September 2014: Alex Duncan, a 26-year-old Australian from Manly, [[Sydney]], died after crashing into a mountain during a jump in the Swiss Alps. He was new to the international wingsuit scene but had been involved with extreme sports since he was a teenager.<ref>Koziol, Michael; Zielinski, Caroline (4 September 2014). [http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/extreme-sports-star-alex-duncan-killed-while-wingsuit-flying-in-swiss-alps-20140904-10c745.html "Extreme sports star Alex Duncan killed while wingsuit flying in Swiss Alps"]. ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]''.</ref> ;14 January 2015: Josh Sheppard, a 31-year-old experienced wingsuit flier and skydiver with more than 3,000 jumps, died when his parachute failed to open after he illegally jumped from a Michigan TV tower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/mich-skydiver-dies-jumping-tv-tower-article-1.2079436 |title=Michigan skydiver dies after jumping from TV tower |publisher=NY Daily News |date=15 January 2015 |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> ;16 May 2015: [[Dean Potter]], 43, and Graham Hunt, 29, died during an illegal wingsuit flight from [[Taft Point]], in [[Yosemite National Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adventureblog.nationalgeographic.com/2015/05/17/pioneering-climber-dean-potter-died-in-base-jumping-accident/ |title=Remembering Pioneering Climber Dean Potter – Beyond the Edge |publisher=Adventureblog.nationalgeographic.com |date= |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> ;3 July 2015: Jhonathan "The Birdman" Florez, a 2013 wingsuiting world champion, died after falling from the exit point at [[Engelberg, Switzerland]].<ref>[http://www.elheraldo.co/deportes/jhonathan-florez-el-hombre-pajaro-ensayaba-un-nuevo-traje-de-salto-cuando-murio-203813 "Jhonathan Flórez, el 'hombre pájaro, ensayaba un nuevo traje de salto cuando murió", from ElHeraldo.com]{{es icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Shammas |first=John |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/jhonathan-florez-dead-world-record-6001295 |title=Jhonathan Florez dead: World record BASE jumper dies 'during parachute exercises while preparing for China tournament' – Mirror Online |publisher=Mirror.co.uk |date=4 July 2015 |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> ;1 October 2015: American [[Johnny Strange (adventurer)|Johnny Strange]], 23, crashed into the ground and died after jumping from a 2,000-metre summit in the Swiss canton of Uri.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-03/american-daredevil-johnny-strange-dies-in-wingsuit-jump/6824952 |title=Johnny Strange: American daredevil dies after wingsuit jump from summit in Switzerland – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=3 October 2015 |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> ;7 June 2016: Brazilian Fernando Brito, 42, died while trying to jump from Pedra da Gávea, Rio de Janeiro.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/rio-de-janeiro/noticia/2016/06/atleta-que-wingsuit-que-morreu-apos-pular-da-pedra-da-gavea-e-velado.html|title=Atleta de wingsuit que morreu após pular da Pedra da Gávea é velado|date=8 June 2016|website=globo.com}}</ref> ;9 June 2016: 33-year-old Italian basejumper star Dario Zanon, known as The Great Dario, one of the world's top wingsuit drivers, died on the side of the French side of Mont Blanc Massif after a failed wingsuit flight from the Aiguille du Midi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/2016/06/13/man-dies-in-mt-blanc-wingsuit-crash_12a45205-9e61-49f9-a0b8-c1d86ee366ff.html|title=Man dies in Mt Blanc wingsuit crash - English|date=13 June 2016|website=ansa.it}}</ref> ;26 June 2016: Gary Kremer, 30-year-old American basejumper and former U.S. Marine, died while wingsuit flying with friends in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/06/27/seattle-man-who-died-base-jumping-in-bc-loved-the-sport-girlfriend-says.html|title=Seattle man who died BASE jumping in B.C. loved the sport, girlfriend says - The Star|website=thestar.com}}</ref> ;17 August 2016: Uli Emanuele, 29-year-old Italian base jumper, died in a crash at Lauterbrunnen in Switzerland while shooting a new video. He was famous for his flights through a ring of fire and a ''needle's eye'' formed by a rock. The other fatality was a 49-year-old Briton who jumped from the High Ultimate peak at Muerren and who also crashed into a cliff. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/2016/08/18/base-jumper-uli-emanuele-dies-3_3ab27d93-d51e-47d2-b740-e581189fde19.html|title=Base jumper Uli Emanuele dies (3) - English|date=18 August 2016|website=ansa.it}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blincmagazine.com/forum/wiki/Uli_Emanuele?redirect=no|title=BLiNC Magazine - BASE Jumping Exit Point: Everything you ever wanted to know about BASE Jumping, Speed Flying and Skydiving but didn't know whom to ask.|website=www.blincmagazine.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/base-jumping-deaths-switzerland-2935413-Aug2016/|title=Two men die in base jumping accidents in Switzerland|first=|last=AFP|website=thejournal.ie}}</ref> ;21 August 2016: Alexander Polli, 31-year-old Italo-Norwegian base jumper, died after crashing into a tree at an altitude of 1,500m near [[Chamonix]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/2016/08/22/base-jumper-alexander-polli-dies-2_2e3f5a80-c6a6-4086-8928-94793b06df80.html|title=Base jumper Alexander Polli dies (2) - English|date=22 August 2016|website=ansa.it}}</ref> ;26 August 2016: Armin Schmieder, 28-year-old Italian base jumper, died after jumping from Kandersteg, in the [[Swiss Alps]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Altri-Mondi/26-08-2016/ancora-base-jumper-morto-volo-schmieder-si-schianta-mentre-gira-video-160936105546.shtml?refresh_ce-cp|title=Ancora un base jumper morto in volo. Schmieder si schianta in diretta Facebook|website=gazzetta.it}}</ref> ;18 November 2016: Mehdi Habibi, Iranian base jumper, died after jumping with Wingsuit from the "High Ultimate" in Lauterbrunnen, Mürren area in the Swiss Alps. He was found dead in rough terrain by a team of Air Glaciers in the afternoon of the same day according to the local police report. His body was subsequently recovered by the rescue team. The incident is believed to have occurred around 9 AM on Friday, 18 November. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.police.be.ch/police/de/index/medien/medien.meldungNeu.html/police/de/meldungen/police/news/2016/11/20161119_1353_lauterbrunnen_basejumpertoedlichverunfallt|title=Lauterbrunnen: Basejumper tödlich verunfallt (Medien) Kantonspolizei Bern - Kanton Bern|website=www.police.be.ch}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/persian/sport-38047231|title=مرگ مهدی حبیبی، قهرمان پرش هوایی ایران|date=21 November 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref> ;27 January 2017: Canadian wingsuit flier Graham Dickinson died after a crash during training in south China. His body was found on a cliff at the Tianmen Mountain National Forest Park in Zhangjiajie of Hunan Province.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.china.org.cn/world/Off_the_Wire/2017-01/27/content_40189321.htm |title=Canadian wingsuit flier dies after crash in China |date=27 January 2017 |accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3219444/canadian-wingsuit-flyer-graham-dickinson-dies-during-base-jump-in-china/ |title=Canadian wingsuit flyer Graham Dickinson dies during BASE jump in China |last=Judd |first=Amy |work=[[Global News]] |date=1 February 2017 |accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref> ;24 May 2017: Matthew Ciancio, a 42-year-old American wingsuit skydiver, died after jumping from 13,000 feet in California as part of a wingsuit formation with "four or five" other people. Ciancio reportedly failed to follow correct emergency procedure to release his main parachute after it did not deploy correctly. Witnesses said he waited too long to release his main parachute and switch to his backup parachute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-skydiver-killed-wingsuit-20170525-story.html|title=Skydiver wearing a wingsuit crashes, dies in Northern California vineyard|first=Associated|last=Press|website=latimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/crime/article152598919.html|title=‘Parachute began spinning’ during deadly skydive, Lodi center official said|first1=Nashelly Chavez, Alexandra|last1=Yoon-Hendricks|first2=Brad|last2=Branan|date=25 May 2017|publisher=|via=Sacramento Bee}}</ref> ;28 June 2017: American resident of Dubai Micah Couch, skydiving instructor, wingsuit flyer and Red Bull Aces wingsuit competitor died during a Wingsuit BASE jump in Aurland, Norway. Witnesses claim that his parachute failed to open, causing him to crash into the base of the mountain. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsinenglish.no/2017/07/02/base-jumper-fatality-sparks-calls-for-a-crackdown/|title=BASE jumper fatality sparks calls for a crackdown|website=www.newsinenglish.no}}</ref> ;6 July 2017: A thirty-year-old man from Switzerland has died after his parachute failed to open during a wingsuit flight in Haute Savoie in France.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://worldradio.ch/news/2017/07/07/swiss-man-dies-in-wingsuit-accident-in-france/|title=Swiss man dies in wingsuit accident in France|date=7 July 2017|website=worldradio.ch}}</ref> ;11 November 2017: [[Valery Rozov]], 52-year-old Russian climb jumper, died while jumping with Wingsuit from a height of 6,812 meters (22,349 ft) off [[Ama Dablam]] mountain in [[Nepal]]. According to members of his group, Rozov crashed into the side of the mountain.<ref>{{cite web|title=A famed Russian daredevil is killed in a BASE-jumping accident|url=http://www.spiegel.de/reise/aktuell/basejumping-walerij-rosow-stirbt-bei-sprung-vom-ama-dablam-a-1177607.html|website=CNN International|language=English|accessdate=21 April 2018}}</ref> ;22 January 2018: Aime-Jean St. Hilaire-Adam, 27-year-old competitive skydiver from Calgary participating in the World Open Wingsuit Championships, was killed after he collided with another jumper, lost consciousness, failed to open his parachute, and crashed onto a roof in [[Perris, California]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Canadian competitive skydiver, 27, who collided with another jumper mid-air and crash-landed on to a roof in freak accident had completed more than 1,000 jumps|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5305077/Canadian-skydiver-killed-accident-elite-jumper.html|website=UK Daily Mail|language=English|accessdate=23 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Calgary skydiver killed after crashing into California home during wingsuit competition|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3981914/skydiver-killed-after-crashing-into-california-home-during-wingsuit-competition/|website=Global News|language=English|accessdate=23 April 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox venue | name = Portland Park | nickname = | image = | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Ashington]], England | coordinates = {{Coord|55.1846|-1.5717|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1909 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 2008 | demolished = | owner = | surface = Grass | cost = | architect = | capacity = | record_attendance = 13,199 | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Ashington A.F.C.]]
[[Ashington Arrows]]
Greyhound racing (1936–1993) }} '''Portland Park''' was a [[association football|football]] ground in [[Ashington]], England. It was the home ground of [[Ashington A.F.C.]] between 1909 and 2008. It also hosted [[Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom|greyhound racing]] from 1936 until 1993.{{cite book|last=Barnes/Sellers|first=Julia/John|title=Ladbrokes Greyhound Fact File|year=1992|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-22-8}} ==History== The ground was opened in 1909 and was initially known as the '''Station Road Ground''' until 1914, when it was renamed Portland Park after the site's landowner the [[William Cavendish-Bentinck, 6th Duke of Portland|Duke of Portland]].[http://www.ashingtonafc.com/info-30-portland-park.html Portland Park] Ashington AFC Ashington had previously played at Station Road, but sought a new ground after [[The Co-operative Group|the Co-op]] decided to double their rent. Ashington were elected to the Third Division North of [[the Football League]] in 1921, by which time the ground had a 1,000-seat grandstand had been built on the northern touchline. After their election to the League the stand was renovated, and the three other sides of the ground had concrete terracing installed. The money for the works was raised by issuing 2,000 shares, which brought in £6,000, and the capacity was raised to 20,000. The first Football League match played at the ground was on 27 August 1921, with Ashington beating [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] 1–0. The attendance of 9,000 was the highest Football League attendance recorded at Portland Park.Paul Smith & Shirley Smith (2005) ''The Ultimate Directory of English & Scottish Football League Grounds Second Edition 1888–2005'', Yore Publications, p103, {{ISBN|0954783042}} Ashington were voted out of the Football League at the end of the [[1928–29 Football League|1928–29 season]], with the last Football League match at Portland Park being a 3–0 defeat to [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]]. The attendance of just 706 was Ashington's lowest during their time in the League. The ground's record attendance of 13,199 was set for an [[FA Cup]] second round match against [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] on 9 December 1950, with Ashington losing 2–1. The ground was no longer used for greyhound racing after 1964, but was subsequently used for [[Motorcycle speedway|speedway]] and [[stock car racing]], becoming the home track of the [[Ashington Arrows]] speedway team. However only two speedway meetings were ever staged in 1972 with [[Phil Crump]] winning the Northumberland Open before the team was forced to leave after sparks led to a stand burning down. ==Greyhound racing== Racing was held from 3 October 1936 through to 1964 when the track closed.{{cite book|last=Furby|first=R|title=Independent Greyhound Racing|pages =88|year=1968|publisher=New Dominion House}} The track re-opened on 16 August 1984, with a circumference of 380 yards. Featuring sharp bends, race distances were 270, 480, and 660 yards.{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}} Racing ended during March 1993. ==Closure== In 2005 it was announced that the site had been sold for a retail development.[http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/asda-way-play-1538595 There Asda be a way to play on] Evening Chronicle, 16 June 2006 Ashington remained at Portland Park until 2008, when they moved to Woodhorn Lane. The last-ever game at the ground was played on 15 February 2008, with Ashington losing 3–2 to [[Seaham Red Star F.C.|Seaham Red Star]] in front of 1,954 spectators. Ashington's final goal at the old ground was scored by centre forward Gareth Bainbridge. The site was used to build an [[Asda]] supermarket.[http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/2054490.print/ Ashington to ashes – the Asda price] Northern Echo, 19 February 2008 ==References== {{reflist}} {{English greyhound tracks}} [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Defunct speedway venues in England]] [[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1909]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Northumberland]] [[Category:Ashington A.F.C.]]

A new, faster course was established for the race in 2010 and 25 km record holder [[Mary Keitany]] duly responded by setting a women's course record of 1:08:46.Fernandes, António Manuel (2010-09-26). [http://www.iaaf.org/LRR10/news/newsid=58393.html Tola and Keitany romp to Half Marathon victories in Lisbon]. [[IAAF]]. Retrieved on 2010-09-27. She returned the following year and defended her title in another women's course record of 1:07:54 hours, while [[Silas Sang]] had his third victory in the men's competition.Fernandes, Antonio Manuel (2011-09-25). [http://www.iaaf.org/LRR11/news/newsid=62628.html Keitany smashes race record in Lisbon]. [[IAAF]]. '''Russian Machine Never Breaks''' ('''RMNB''') is a credentialed [[Washington, D.C.]] area hockey [[blog]] that covers [[professional ice hockey]]. Created in 2009, RMNB received local and national [[#Media attention|media attention]] when it was the first U.S. media outlet to cover the [[2013 Russian meteor event]] in the city of [[Chelyabinsk]], [[Russia]]. RMNB has been featured on Fox News DC and [[NPR]] ''[[Weekend Edition Sunday]]'', and in '' [[The Atlantic]]''.
==About== RMNB is a fan-operated, credentialed, multinational hockey blog that covers the [[Washington Capitals]] of the [[National Hockey League]], the [[Hershey Bears]] (the Capitals' [[American Hockey League]] affiliate), and their respective players. Created in 2009 by [[#Ian Oland|Ian Oland]] and [[#Peter Hassett|Peter Hassett]], RMNB's mission is to "make hockey as fun to read about as it is to watch".<ref>{{cite web|last=Hassett|first=Peter|title=About RMNB|url=http://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/about-rmnb/|work=blog|accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> RMNB takes its name from current Capitals captain and Russian native, [[Alexander Ovechkin]]. In response to questions from the media about a potential injury after being hit with a puck, Ovechkin was quoted in 2006 stating, "I'm okay; Russian machine never breaks."<ref>{{cite news|last=El-Bashir|first=Tarik|title=Caps' 'Russian Machine' Fine After Puck Hits Foot|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/26/AR2006102601518.html|accessdate=16 February 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=27 October 2006}}</ref>
In February 2013, RMNB received local and national media attention when co-founder and writer Peter Hassett, with contributing writers [[#Fedor Fedin|Fedor Fedin]] and Ian Oland, published the first U.S. media report about the [[#2013_Russian_meteor_event|Russian meteor event]].<ref name=":0">{{cite news|url=http://www.myfoxdc.com/video?autoStart=true&topVideoCatNo=default&clipId=8400568#.UR-4IcTrKrs.gmail|title=Hockey Website Helps Break Russia Meteor News|last=Thomas|first=Will|date=15 February 2013|accessdate=16 February 2013|newspaper=Fox News DC}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/02/17/172235263/how-a-hockey-blog-got-the-scoop-on-the-russias-meteor|title=How A Hockey Blog Got The Scoop On The Russia's Meteor|last=Martin|first=Rachel|date=17 February 2013|accessdate=17 February 2013|newspaper=NPR}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/02/how-a-dc-hockey-fan-site-got-the-russian-meteorite-story-before-the-ap/273225/|title=How a DC Hockey Fan Site Got the Russian Meteorite Story Before the AP|last=Franke-Ruta|first=Garance|date=15 February 2013|accessdate=16 February 2013|newspaper=The Atlantic}}</ref>
In November 2013, the Washington Capitals announced that RMNB would contribute segments to their Emmy-winning television show, ''Caps Red Line''.<ref>{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Sixth Season of Caps Red Line to Debut on Nov. 19 on Monumental Network |url=http://capitals.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=691608 |location=Arlington, Virginia |publisher=[[Washington Capitals]] |date=2013-11-15 |accessdate=2013-12-05}}</ref>
==Staff== Russian Machine Never Breaks has eight contributors. All staff members work full-time for other companies or are pursuing academic degrees in the United States and abroad.
===Ian Oland=== Ian Oland is RMNB's co-founder (with Peter Hassett) and publisher. He is a graduate of [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]] and works as the Senior Email Marketing Design Strategist at Visual Data Systems. His work has been published in ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/dc-sports-bog/wp/2014/08/01/orioles-top-prospect-dylan-bundy-re-learns-how-to-pitch-after-tommy-john-surgery/</ref>
===Peter Hassett=== Peter Hassett is RMNB's co-founder (with Ian Oland) and managing editor. Hassett writes game recaps and analysis. He is a graduate of [[James Madison University]] and works as the Director of Technology at Patient Solutions at DrugDev.
===Chris Gordon=== Chris Gordon is a writer and photographer for RMNB. His work has been published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gordon|first=Chris|url=http://slapshot.blogs.nytimes.com/author/chris-gordon/|accessdate=16 February 2013|newspaper=New York Times|title=Capitals Goalie Takes Rapid Rise Save by Save}}</ref>
===Fedor Fedin=== Fedor Fedin is a translator and prospect/draft writer for RMNB. He attends college in Moscow, Russia.
===Igor Kleyner=== Igor Kleyner is a Russian translator and interviewer for RMNB.
===Rachel Cohen=== Rachel Cohen is the blog's lead illustrator. After graduating from the [[University of Hartford]] in 2013, she now interns with the [[Washington Kastles]].
===Former staff=== Former writer Neil Greenberg is currently a writer for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and [[ESPN]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Neil|title=Neil Greenberg News|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/neil-greenberg/|accessdate=27 April 2017|newspaper=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/neil-greenberg|title=Neil Greenberg|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref> Former members Doug Johnson and Craig Brownstein wrote game previews and other articles. Oksana Zolotar later worked with the game night staff for the Washington Capitals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://capitals.nhl.com/v2/ext/Washington_Capitals_2012_13_Media_Guide.pdf|title=2012 2013 Washington Capitals Official Guide|last=|first=|date=April 27, 2017|website=Washington Capitals|access-date=}}</ref>
==Notable Coverage==
===2013 Russian meteor event===
On February 14, 2013, Peter Hassett was contacted by Moscow correspondent Fedor Fedin about reports of an explosion in [[Chelyabinsk]], Russia. The writers were following news about Chelyabinsk because it's the hometown of Capitals center [[Evgeny Kuznetsov]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Whyno|first=Stephen|title=Capitals still 'prepared to wait' for Evgeny Kuznetsov|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/blog/capitals-watch/2012/jun/14/capitals-still-prepared-wait-evgeny-kuznetsov/|accessdate=16 February 2013|newspaper=Washington Times|date=14 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625113201/http://www.washingtontimes.com/blog/capitals-watch/2012/jun/14/capitals-still-prepared-wait-evgeny-kuznetsov/|archivedate=25 June 2012|df=}}</ref> By gathering information from [[social media]] videos and [[Twitter]], including an account from former NHL goalie [[Michael Garnett]] and other eyewitnesses, Fedin and Hassett discovered that a meteor had hit Chelyabinsk, and Hassett (with additional reporting by Fedin and Ian Oland) published the news on their blog.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2013/02/14/what-is-happening-in-chelyabinsk/|title=Explosions in Chelyabinsk; Meteor Suspected (UPDATED)|date=2013-02-15|website=Russian Machine Never Breaks|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref>
Following the story, Hassett was interviewed by [[Garance Franke-Ruta]], a senior editor at ''[[The Atlantic]]''. He confirmed that he published the article a little after 11:00 p.m. EST. Franke-Ruta wrote that [[The Associated Press]] did not break the news until 12:21 a.m. EST Friday, confirming that Hassett and RMNB were the first to report the story in the United States. After Franke-Ruta's story was published, other news outlets began to pick up the story.<ref name=":2" />
On Friday evening, Hassett was interviewed by Will Thomas of Fox News DC who also confirmed that RMNB was the first to report on the meteor. On Sunday morning February 17, 2013, Hassett and Gordon were interviewed by NPR's ''Weekend Edition Sunday'' host, [[Rachel Martin (broadcast journalist)|Rachel Martin]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> On this broadcast Martin confirmed that RMNB was the first to break the story in the United States by "about an hour and a half".
Though not affiliated with the Washington Capitals nor endorsed by them, the Capitals' owner, [[Ted Leonsis]], congratulated RMNB for its coverage of the meteor event.<ref>{{cite web|last=Leonsis|first=Ted|title=Bravo RMNB|url=http://tedstake.monumentalnetwork.com/bravo-rmnb/index.jsp|publisher=Monumental Network|accessdate=20 February 2013}}</ref>
===Michal Neuvirth translation controversy=== In August 2012, Russian Machine Never Breaks published a translation of an interview given by Washington Capitals goaltender [[Michal Neuvirth]] to František Suchan of iSportz.Cz.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2012/08/20/michal-neuvirth-i-advised-vokoun-to-go-to-the-penguins-holtby-is-my-weakest-competition-yet/|title=Michal Neuvirth: I Advised Vokoun to Go to the Penguins; Holtby is my Weakest Competition Yet|date=2012-08-21|website=Russian Machine Never Breaks|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref>
The interview contained controversial remarks about current teammate [[Braden Holtby]], Capitals' captain Alexander Ovechkin, former teammate [[Alexander Semin]], former coach [[Dale Hunter]], and other Capitals players. The interview was picked up by hockey media in the United States and internationally.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/capitals-insider/post/michal-neuvirth-alex-ovechkin-isnt-what-he-used-to-be/2012/08/21/9aebc9d2-eb95-11e1-a80b-9f898562d010_blog.html|title=Michal Neuvirth: Alex Ovechkin ‘isn’t what he used to be’|last=Applebaum|first=Lindsay|date=21 August 2012|accessdate=16 February 2013|newspaper=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Nichols|first=Chris|title=Neuvirth: Ovechkin 'isn't what he used to be'|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/2012/08/21/neuvirth_unleashed/|accessdate=16 February 2013|newspaper=SportsNet|date=21 August 2012}}</ref> The following news outlets published all or parts of RMNB's translation: [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/capitals-insider/post/michal-neuvirth-alex-ovechkin-isnt-what-he-used-to-be/2012/08/21/9aebc9d2-eb95-11e1-a80b-9f898562d010_blog.html Washington Post], [http://aol.sportingnews.com/nhl/story/2012-08-21/michal-neuvirth-tweaks-braden-holtby-alex-ovechkin-washington-capitals Sporting News], [http://prohockeytalk.nbcsports.com/2012/08/21/michal-neuvirth-sounds-off-on-semin-ovechkin-and-dale-hunter/ NBC Sports ProHockey Talk], [http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/2012/08/21/neuvirth_unleashed/ NHL SportsNet], and [https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nhl-puck-daddy/capitals-goalie-michal-neuvirth-thinks-braden-holtby-weakest-025232112--nhl.html Yahoo Sports].
In response to the coverage, Michal Neuvirth conducted an interview with Washington Capitals senior writer Mike Vogel where he commented that "there was some misunderstanding. They changed my meaning a lot. I was talking about the boys in a good way. They translate to the way they want it. I feel like they got nothing to write about right now."<ref>{{cite web|title=Checking in with Michal Neuvirth|url=http://video.capitals.nhl.com/videocenter/console?id=185497|work=Video|publisher=Washington Capitals|accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Neuvirth was also quoted by NHL News and [[Sportsnet]], saying the interview was mistranslated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=640409|title=Neuvirth: Comments on Capitals translated wrong|website=NHL.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/nhl/michal-neuvirth-washington-capitals-comments-mistranslated/|title=Neuvirth: Capitals criticisms mistranslated - Sportsnet.ca|work=Sportsnet.ca|access-date=2017-04-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
On August 21, 2012, RMNB responded to criticisms of their translation by publishing a clarification about the interview. Hassett wrote, "While we stand by the articles we published, we acknowledge that translation is as much an art as it is an academic skill."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hassett|first=Peter|title=A Clarification on the Neuvirth Interview and a Note on Translations|url=http://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2012/08/21/a-clarification-on-the-neuvirth-interview-and-a-note-on-translations/|publisher=Russian Machine Never Breaks|accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> He wrote that, "Neuvirth’s meaning may have been misconstrued." However, in a post on August 30, 2012, RMNB announced that its team had hired a professional translation firm, [[TransPerfect]], to objectively translate the Neuvirth interview. RMNB compared TransPerfect's translation and its own side by side.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2012/08/30/the-neuvirth-translation-verification-and-attribution/|title=The Neuvirth Translation: Verification and Attribution|date=2012-08-31|website=Russian Machine Never Breaks|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref> After review, RMNB stands by its translation as the writers felt the professional translation and their own were nearly identical in meaning and therefore accurate.
===Tim Thomas "Obama" Signs and Masks=== Leading into the Capitals 2011-12 Eastern Conference Quarterfinals matchup against the [[Boston Bruins]], Hassett published an article discussing [[Tim Thomas (ice hockey)|Tim Thomas]]'s performance after he snubbed the U.S. president [[Barack Obama]] during the Bruins' [[Stanley Cup]] celebration at the White House. Via a chart, Hassett showed that as Obama's approval rating got stronger, Thomas's save percentage got weaker.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://russianmachineneverbreaks.tumblr.com/post/21209802241/tim-thomass-save-percentage-vs-barack-obamas|title=Russian Machine Never Breaks, Tim Thomas’s save percentage vs. Barack Obama’s...|website=Russian Machine Never Breaks|language=en|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref> Because of this, Oland also made Obama signs and masks to try and throw Thomas off his game. Many Capitals fans in game three printed the signs out and wore the masks, gaining the blog national attention. [[Hockey Night in Canada]] did a segment on the posts during their live coverage of the game, ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' wrote a story about it, and [[ESPN|ESPN's]] [[Pardon the Interruption]] discussed the signs and masks the next day on its show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2012/04/16/photos-caps-fans-taunt-tim-thomas-with-obama-signs/|title=Photos: Caps Fans Taunt Tim Thomas With Obama Signs|date=2012-04-17|website=Russian Machine Never Breaks|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/17/tim-thomas-obama-signs-capitals-fans_n_1431367.html|title=Caps Fans Use Obama To Taunt Bruins Star|last=Klopman|first=Michael|date=17 April 2012|work=Huffington Post}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2012/04/17/ptis-michael-wilbon-tony-kornheiser-discuss-obama-signs/|title=PTI’s Michael Wilbon & Tony Kornheiser Discuss Obama Signs|date=2012-04-18|website=Russian Machine Never Breaks|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref>
===Barack the Red White House Campaign=== The Barack the Red campaign is a petition by Capitals fans for former President [[Barack Obama]] to attend a Washington Capitals game.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/barackthered/|title=Barack The Red {{!}} Help RMNB Get President Obama To A Washington Capitals Game|website=www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref> The campaign was started by Ian Oland, co-founder of Russian Machine Never Breaks. The Barack the Red website features an open letter to President Obama and a petition with a link to the [[Facebook]] page where supporters are asked to "like" the page to show support for the campaign.
In 2011, [[Robert Gibbs]], a senior campaign advisor for Barack Obama, was asked if President Obama were planning to attend a Washington Capitals game.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Gibbs Is Asked if President Obama Will Barack The Red|url=http://vimeo.com/10144016#at=0|accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> The reporter, [[The Washington Post|''The Washington Post''<nowiki/>'s]] Scott Wilson referenced the Barack the Red campaign started by Oland.
President Obama has not attended a Washington Capitals game.
===2015 Winter Classic Jerseys=== On September 22, 2014, Russian Machine Never Breaks revealed images from inside DC's [[Nationals Park]] that suggested the [[Washington Capitals]] would be introducing a new logo for the [[2015 NHL Winter Classic]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2014/09/22/is-this-the-capitals-logo-for-the-2015-winter-classic/ | title=Is This the Capitals' Logo for the 2015 Winter Classic? | publisher=Russian Machine Never Breaks | accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> The following day, RMNB was the first to post leaked images of the new Winter Classic jerseys prior to their official unveiling.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2014/09/23/the-capitals-new-winter-classic-jersey/|title=The Capitals New Winter Classic Jersey|publisher=Russian Machine Never Breaks|accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nhl/story/2014-09-23/washington-capitals-winter-classic-jersey-logo-design|title=Washington Capitals Winter Classic Jersey Logo Design|publisher=The Sporting News|accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/dcsportsbog/status/514453184438616065|title=Dan Steinberg on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2017-04-27|language=en}}</ref>

2017, 2018 }} '''Savina Ski Jumping Center''' is a [[ski jumping]] complex located in [[Ljubno ob Savinji]], Slovenia. ==History== The first ski jumping competition in Ljubno was held in 1931. In 1949, the construction of the new K-60 hill began. The hill was planned and constructed by [[Stanko Bloudek]], who also constructed the [[Letalnica bratov Gorišek]] ski flying hill. The construction was completed in 1952. The smaller training hills (K-18 nad K-20) were constructed in 1974 and 1955, respectively. The local ski jumping club ''SSK Ljubno'' was founded in 1973. In 1983, the K-20 hill was covered with plastic mate. In 2005, the venue was reconstructed according to the modern regulations set by the [[International Ski Federation]]. In 2015, the venue underwent major renovation. The venue hosted twelve [[Fédération Internationale de Ski|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]] events for ladies as of 2018. [[Daniela Iraschko-Stolz]] holds the hill record with 96.6 metres.{{cite news|url=https://www.rtvslo.si/sport/zimski-sporti/mmc-tv-smucarski-skoki-na-ljubnem/414846|title=Trojna nemška zmaga na Ljubnem, Ema Klinec znova peta|date=12 February 2017|accessdate=12 February 2017|language=sl|author=D. '''[[Singapore]]''' competed at the '''[[1960 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]. Five competitors, all men, took part in three events in three sports.<ref name="SportsRef">{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/SIN/summer/1960/ |title=Singapore at the 1960 Rome Summer Games |accessdate=29 June 2015 |work=Sports Reference}}</ref> This marked the first and only time Singapore competed at the Olympics as a self-governing colony of the United Kingdom under what would later become the national flag. [[Tan Howe Liang]] won the territory's first ever Olympic medal, its only medal until 2008.
==Medalists==
=== Silver=== *[[Tan Howe Liang]] — [[Weightlifting at the 1960 Summer Olympics|weightlifting]], men's lightweight
The following Singaporean athletes participated in the games:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snoc.org.sg/files/OlympicGamesParticipants.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203163051/http://www.snoc.org.sg/files/OlympicGamesParticipants.pdf |archivedate=3 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Sailing== {{main|Sailing at the 1960 Summer Olympics}} *[[Cooke James Bryden]] *[[Durcan Thomas Kevin]] *[[Holiday Edward Gilbert]]
==Shooting== {{main|Shooting at the 1960 Summer Olympics}} One shooter reperesented Singapore in 1960.
;[[Shooting at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre pistol|50 m pistol]] * [[Kok Kum Woh]]
==Weightlifting== {{main|Weightlifting at the 1960 Summer Olympics}} *[[Tan Howe Liang]] (2nd place)

{{Refimprove|date=June 2008}} {{Manual|date=April 2010}}
''This article is about hunting platforms. For a stand of trees, see [[Grove (nature)]].''
'''Tree stands''' or '''deer stands''' are open or enclosed platforms used by [[hunter]]s. The platforms are secured to trees in order to elevate the hunter and give him or her a better vantage point. A tripod stand is a similar device, but because it is freestanding rather than attached to a tree, it is not technically a tree stand.
==Types== [[Hunters]] use many different types of tree stands. [[File:Tree stand.jpg|thumb|Ladder-style tree stand]]
===Climbing stand=== Two parts make up climbing stands. The bottom part is the standing platform and the top is the seat. Not all the top parts have backs for the seats. There is normally a strap that connects the two parts, so if the bottom falls while in the tree or climbing, the platform doesn’t fall all the way to the ground, stranding the hunter. Only trees that have no limbs up to the height desired for hunting will work.
Climbing tree stands have a couple of different styles to connect to the tree. The part that wraps around the tree can be made from a thick cable or [[boomerang]] shaped piece of [[metal]]. The part that wraps around the tree is fastened to the stand with a [[Screw|bolt]] or [[pin]] for easy adjustment for different tree sizes.
Before climbing the tree both parts need to be adjusted to the tree so that both upper and lower parts are angled up to account for the narrowing of the tree. To climb the tree the back of each part is angled to the tree one at a time and pulled up. Then the part that the hunter is moving is set back level and the next part is moved up. This is done until the hunter is at the desired height. In addition to the tree stand, some hunters use a safety harness to prevent injury in the event that any component of the tree stand fails. You should always be connected to the tree for safety. To descend the tree, the hunter simply reverses the order of operations to climb the tree - lowering the standing platform, standing on the standing platform, then lowering the sitting platform.
===Ladder stand=== Ladder stands are a stand with a seat and platform along with the ladder to climb up into the stand. A ladder stand has a seat and platform that connect to the tree with the ladder coming off the front of the platform to give the hunter access to the stand. Ladder stands are stationary because of the size and lack of ability to move through the woods quietly. Stability is good because of the connection to the tree and support from the ground. Hunters can use one and two person ladder stands.
===Hanging stand=== Hanging stands can resemble ladder stands without the ladder, and the hanging stand is also stationary. Hanging stands connect to the tree with chains or cables at the desired height. To get up to a hanging stand hunters use ladders or sections of ladders secured to the tree (called "climbing sticks"), or they use screw in steps that screw in the tree and allow the hunter to climb up to the stand.
===Box stand=== [[File:Elevated hunting blind.jpg|thumb|Elevated "Box" type [[hunting blind]]]] Box stands are large enclosed stands that almost look like a shed, they can be built to various heights with ladders or steps to enter when elevated. These are designed to help get out of the weather and keep you hidden from view of game. Most are made from lumber with plywood walls and flooring with a wood or metal roof. They are designed mostly for use along the edge of fields, where you can see long distances.
==Uses== The inherent functional flexibility of tree stands allows hunters to use them in different ways. [[Whitetail deer]] are the most popular animal to hunt out of a tree stand,{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} but other animals can be hunted from tree stands.
Tree stands can give the hunter an advantage, as the hunter sits up in a tree. This allows the hunter to see over intervening brush and vegetation that might otherwise block the hunter's view of approaching game. The advantage is not always clear, however, as early fall hunting in hardwoods bottoms can result in shortened line of sight, mostly because of heavy foliage still on the trees. This can be remedied by cutting shooting lanes for bows and firearms to see better from the tree stand.
Hunters use climbing stands to take the stand to different locations easily. Although not permanent like ladder stands and hanging stands, they can relocate a hunter to a different tree easily. Some hunters do leave them in the woods at the base of the tree. Climbing stands allow hunters that want to hunt from them to use a climbing stand at a location that will not allow them to keep a stand up during the whole season. Often ladder stands and hanging stands do not move easily, so they tend to stay on one tree. Because branches limit climbing stand use, ladder stands and hanging stands allow hunters more options on the trees with many branches at a lower height.
A few accessories are available for tree stands. Rope from the stand to the ground allows the hunter to pull up accessories or their weapon once in the stand. Besides the safety, hanging, ladder, and rope equipment, hunters can get:
* Bow holders * Shooting rests * Blinds for around the stand * Covers over the stand * Umbrellas to protect the hunter from rain * Seat pads * Camouflage tape to disguise the stand
==Safety== [[Safety]] is the biggest consideration for tree stands. A body [[Climbing harness|harness]] is the most important part of tree stand safety. Many different styles of harness can keep hunters safe. One harness compiled of a belt around the waist of the person and one around tree with a strap between the two can keep the hunter safe. Another harness is a full body harness, which has shoulder straps and straps around the legs. The full body harness attaches to the tree the same way the belt harness does. Attaching the harness as soon as the hunter is in the tree keeps the hunter safe while setting up for the hunt. The strap between the harness and strap around the tree should be long enough to allow the hunter to move a little and short enough so if the hunter falls they do not fall too far.
Tree stand users should always check over their stands to ensure good working condition. A tree stand in poor condition can be unsafe for the hunter to hunt from. Checking the steps up to the stand for safely and stability can prevent falling while climbing up to the stand.
Never carry equipment while climbing. Use a haul line to raise or lower your equipment.
==See also== *[[Deer hunting]] *[[Stand level modelling]] *[[Tree shelter]]
